sheer curtains: alternatives and explain meaning

Sheer curtains = lightweight, translucent curtains that let daylight through while softening the view and giving limited daytime privacy. Common fabrics: voile, net, lace, organza.

Good alternatives/near-synonyms:
- US: sheers, sheer curtains, voile curtains, lace curtains
- UK: net curtains, voile curtains, lace curtains
- Descriptive: gauzy curtains, semi-sheer curtains (slightly less transparent), light‑filtering curtains (marketing term; may be less sheer)

Notes:
- “Sheer” implies very see‑through; “semi‑sheer” is a touch more opaque.
- They provide privacy mainly in daylight; at night with lights on, sheers alone are see‑through, so people pair them with heavier drapes or blinds. 
- Polish firanki typically corresponds to net/voile/lace sheers.

what is roe venison

“Roe venison” is the meat of a roe deer (Capreolus capreolus in Europe; not fish “roe”). It’s a lean, fine‑grained venison with a mild, slightly sweet, delicate game flavor. Common cuts include saddle/loin, haunch, and shoulder; it’s often cooked rare to medium‑rare.

what is a practicum alternate?

“Practicum” = a supervised, for‑credit period of practical training as part of a course or degree (common in education, psychology, social work, nursing).

Good alternatives, depending on context/region:
- Internship (US; broad, sometimes paid; can be outside coursework)
- Fieldwork / clinical (hands‑on training in health/social services)
- Placement / work placement (UK/Commonwealth)
- Student teaching / teaching practice (teacher training)
- Externship (short, observational, US)
- Clinical rotation / clerkship (medical school)
- Residency (post‑MD training; not the same as practicum)
- Apprenticeship / traineeship (trades or employment‑based training)
- Co‑op (cooperative education; alternating study and paid work)

For Polish “praktyka/praktyka zawodowa,” “work placement,” “internship,” or “practical training” are usually the best fits.

gminie której budynek stał ,explain

- Meaning: “w gminie, której budynek stał przy głównej drodze” = “at the gmina (municipality/commune), whose building stood by the main road.”
- Notes:
  - gmina = Polish administrative unit; in speech it often means the gmina office (urząd gminy).
  - której = feminine genitive singular relative pronoun (“whose”), referring back to gmina; it marks possession: the building of the gmina.

C. K. Austrian building , explain

“C.K.” = cesarsko‑królewski, i.e., “imperial and royal” (German: k.k. for the Austrian half; k.u.k. for joint institutions of Austria‑Hungary). 

So a “C.K. Austrian building” means a Habsburg/Austro‑Hungarian era building—typically an administrative, military, school, court, post or railway structure built under Austrian rule (in Galicia) in the late 19th–early 20th century, often in historicist or Secession (Art Nouveau) styles.

Natural English: “a Habsburg‑era building,” “an Austro‑Hungarian (imperial‑and‑royal) building,” or “a former Austrian partition‑era building.”
